Turing Award 1991

Winner: Arthur John Robin Gorell ("Robin") Milner

Robin Milner won the Turing Award in 1991 for three distinct contributions

  • LCF (Logic for Computable Functions)
  • ML (Programming language)
  • CCS (Calculus of communicating systems)

LCF

The Logic for Computable Functions system was developed by Robin Milner and his collaborators in 1970. It is an interactive theorem prover that lets users create their own rules for solving complex functions.
Theorems are terms of a special type of abstract data type that can be computed using the general mechanism of ML. The correctness of the derived theorems is computed by the ML compiler after taking into account the various features of the system.

ML

Meta Language is a general-purpose programming language that uses the Hindley-Milner type system to automatically assign the types of most expressions. It is also known for its pattern matching capabilities.
Features of ML include call-by-value evaluation, automatic memory management, first-class functions, and many more. ML is considered an impure functional language, because it allows side effects while encouraging functional programming. It's a general purpose language and nowadays there are even several languages that are part of the ML family, such as StandardML, f#, OCaml, CakeML, and many more.

CCS

The calculus of communicating systems is a process calculus that was introduced around 1980 by Miller.
To make it simple, it's a branch of calculus that occupies of determining and modeling actions between two participants. It is used to describe parallel composition and also to evaluate the correctness of systems of states.
